replies.msg:
Here's a short chunk of a speech by Winston Churchill:

Armed men are in a category absolutely different from unarmed men. An unarmed crowd stands in a totally different position from an armed crowd. At Amritsar the crowd was neither armed nor attacking. [Interruption.] I carefully said that when I used the word "armed" I meant armed with lethal weapons, or with firearms. There is no dispute between us on that point. "I was confronted," says General Dyer, "by a revolutionary army." What is the chief characteristic of an army? Surely it is that it is armed. This crowd was unarmed. These are simple tests which it is not too much to expect officers in these difficult situations to apply.

(from: https://api.parliament.uk/historic-hansard/commons/1920/jul/08/army-council-and-general-dyer)

It relates to a massacre in India during British rule and Churchill gave a rather lengthy speech condemning the British officer in charge. I listened to it as an audio recording a while back and was surprised at how relevant it was to HK and China. I think that speech cemented Western attitudes towards revolts, uprising, and massacres. It set the rules that we've tried to play by for a century.

If you want the support of the Western world, and you need it, then don't break those rules. Protesters are allowed a certain class of weapons. If you use the other class, firearms... even bows and arrows, then you are no longer protesting. You are an army and armies can be legitimately slaughtered.

Don't go there.

replies.msg:
There are chemistry classes at university too... doesn't make it okay to build a bomb.

Whataboutism is a trap for the protesters. Don't do it, doesn't matter what they do... and the worse they do the better for you. But, you can't do it too.

So far their frame-ups, committing acts and then trying to blame the results on the protesters has failed. Too many eyes, to many recordings, too many people fact-checking the results, and you have a much better ability to distribute your message.

I'm not saying don't be violent. I'm not saying don't destroy property. What I'm saying is that there are a class of weapons you can use and another class you cannot. Know the difference and play by the rules if you want to keep support.

The whole contest is about trying to push the other side into breaking the rules. You need to continue to push the police into unreasonable force. You need to draw in the PLA without them having good reason to be there. That is how you win. But, whatever you do, don't let them push you into breaking the rules. You can't win if you do.

Remember your goals. Achieving your goals requires you raise the cost of the CCP continuing their current path. The ONLY way you can do that is with Western public support, support demanding their governments take economic and political action against the CCP. That is the cost of their actions against you. Dead police don't cost them, destroyed property doesn't cost them. They would prefer you do that as it makes the real cost they have to pay less. You will lose support from the west and the west will, in turn, continue to do business with the CCP, thus helping them survive.

Economics is the only support you're going to get. No one is going to HK to fight a war with the CCP. That would, at best, destroy HK. At worst, destroy the world. It's not going to happen.

What can happen is that the Chinese economy is separated from the rest of the world and the Chinese people give up on the CCP, destroying it from the inside. That's the long-term goal.

replies.msg:
Propaganda, as a word, probably does not translate well. It can have a lot of negative meanings attached that I do not intend.

When I say "propaganda," I mean: a Lennon Wall, posters, internet memes, citizen news conferences, spreading your message. Your message, the protester message, dominates the news pretty much everywhere in the West. In the contest to control the dominant message, the protesters are winning everywhere I look (and I'll admit to not looking inside China). The CCP's attempts are pathetic in comparison; their 50cent Army a joke. Literally, a joke, if not an outright insult.

You mention the false-flag attacks (undercover police making protesters look bad). The protesters have caught them, again and again, such that the dominant message is "oh, are they undercover cops." That is controlling the message. Again, the protesters are winning here.

Propaganda, as I mean it, spreads a message. The truthfulness of that message is ... I'm trying to find the right word that will translate properly: relative, contextual, dependent on views. It is also often exaggerated or made absolute where reality is more flexible. This is normal in a conflict, necessary even. Messages need to be packed small and there's no room for "it depends."

Take the HK police for example. The message is that they are killing people. That message is universal, to the point where everyone is calling them murderers everywhere they go. Statistics say otherwise. They can't all be murderers because there aren't enough dead people. There are 30,000 HK police. There are not 30,000 bodies. But, everywhere they go, they are all called murderers, and that's a good thing. That's what happens in a conflict. It's part of war. It is obviously having a psychological effect on the police. It's helping you win.

But, when you are surrounded by police, remember that "the HK police are murderers" is your message and that the truth is more subtle. Surrendering is not certain death. Odds are, surrendering will turn out a lot better than the alternatives. Do not be a victim of your own exaggerated message.

That is what I am trying to say.
